message_text: Paper Title: Colloquium: Quantum and classical discrete time crystals Paper Abstract: The spontaneous breaking of time translation symmetry has led to the discovery of a new phase of matter - the discrete time crystal. Discrete time crystals exhibit rigid subharmonic oscillations, which result from a combination of many-body interactions, collective synchronization, and ergodicity breaking. This Colloquium reviews recent theoretical and experimental advances in the study of quantum and classical discrete time crystals. We focus on the breaking of ergodicity as the key to discrete time crystals and the delaying of ergodicity as the source of numerous phenomena that share many of the properties of discrete time crystals, including the AC Josephson effect, coupled map lattices, and Faraday waves. Theoretically, there exists a diverse array of strategies to stabilize time crystalline order in both closed and open systems, ranging from localization and prethermalization to dissipation and error correction. Experimentally, many-body quantum simulators provide a natural platform for investigating signatures of time crystalline order; recent work utilizing trapped ions, solid-state spin systems, and superconducting qubits will be reviewed. Finally, this Colloquium concludes by describing outstanding challenges in the field and a vision for new directions on both the experimental and theoretical fronts. "contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.) "survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work) task - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding) method - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction) data - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus) artifact - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9) tool - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope) concept - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory) other - Entities that don't fit above categories uses - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks) proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS: - ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work) - CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new) { "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey", "triples": [ { "name": "Wikipedia Article Title", "relation": "uses|proposes", "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other", "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...", "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)" } ] } FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool: CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do. 1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field. 2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation. 3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia. 4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm") - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes) - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/) - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters 5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py 6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes. When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter: WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"]) This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains. Begin now.

Web search results for query: "AC Josephson effect"

Links: [{"title":"Josephson effect - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Josephson_effect"},{"title":"Josephson diode - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Josephson_diode"},{"title":"Josephson voltage standard - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Josephson_voltage_standard"},{"title":"Talk:Josephson effect - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Josephson_effect"},{"title":"Category:Josephson effect - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Josephson_effect"},{"title":"Magnetic flux quantum - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Josephson_constant"},{"title":"Brian Josephson - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brian_Josephson"},{"title":"Pi Josephson junction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pi_Josephson_junction"},{"title":"Phi Josephson junction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phi_Josephson_junction"},{"title":"Josephson junction count - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Josephson_junction_count"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about the AC Josephson effect:

## Overview

The Josephson effect is a phenomenon that occurs when two superconductors are placed in proximity, with some barrier or restriction between them. The effect is named after the British physicist Brian Josephson, who predicted in 1962 the mathematical relationships for the current and voltage across the weak link.

## The AC Josephson Effect Specifically

Josephson discovered that when there is a voltage drop across a Josephson junction, the current should oscillate at a frequency related to the drop in voltage. This oscillating behavior is what characterizes the ACJosephson effect—when a voltage is applied across a Josephson junction, an alternating current oscillates at a frequency proportional to that voltage.

## Components

The Josephson effect produces a current, known as a supercurrent, that flows continuously without any voltage applied, across a device known as a Josephson junction (JJ). This consists of two or more superconductors coupled by a weak link.

## Significance

The Josephson effect has many practical applications because it exhibits a precise relationship between different physical measures, such as voltage and frequency, facilitating highly accurate measurements.(no content)It is the most accurate method to generate or measure voltage and has been, since an international agreement in 1990, the basis for voltage standards around the world.

Based on the search results, here's information about the AC Josephson effect:

## Overview

The Josephson effect is a phenomenon that occurs when two superconductors are placed in proximity, with some barrier or restriction between them. The effect is named after the British physicist Brian Josephson, who predicted in 1962 the mathematical relationships for the current and voltage across the weak link.

## The AC Josephson Effect Specifically

Josephson discovered that when there is a voltage drop across a Josephson junction, the current should oscillate at a frequency related to the drop in voltage. This oscillating behavior is what characterizes the ACJosephson effect—when a voltage is applied across a Josephson junction, an alternating current oscillates at a frequency proportional to that voltage.

## Components

The Josephson effect produces a current, known as a supercurrent, that flows continuously without any voltage applied, across a device known as a Josephson junction (JJ). This consists of two or more superconductors coupled by a weak link.

## Significance

The Josephson effect has many practical applications because it exhibits a precise relationship between different physical measures, such as voltage and frequency, facilitating highly accurate measurements.(no content)It is the most accurate method to generate or measure voltage and has been, since an international agreement in 1990, the basis for voltage standards around the world.

Links: [{"title":"Ergodic hypothesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ergodic_hypothesis"},{"title":"Ergodicity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ergodicity"},{"title":"Ergodic process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ergodic_process"},{"title":"Ergodicity economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ergodicity_economics"},{"title":"Quantum ergodicity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_ergodicity"},{"title":"Ergodic theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ergodic_theory"},{"title":"Stationary ergodic process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stationary_ergodic_process"},{"title":"Eigenstate thermalization hypothesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eigenstate_thermalization_hypothesis"},{"title":"Talk:Ergodic hypothesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Ergodic_hypothesis"},{"title":"Ergodic literature - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ergodic_literature"}]

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of ergodicity breaking:

## Definition and General Concept

In macroscopic systems, the timescales over which a system can truly explore the entirety of its own phase space can be sufficiently large that the thermodynamic equilibrium state exhibits some form of ergodicity breaking.

To understand this, it helps to know that ergodicity means the ensemble average equals the time average. When ergodicity breaks, this equivalence no longer holds.

## Examples in Physics

A classic example is spontaneous magnetisation in ferromagnetic systems, whereby below the Curie temperature the system preferentially adopts a non-zero magnetisation even though the ergodic hypothesis would imply that no net magnetisation should exist by virtue of the system exploring all states whose time-averaged magnetisation should be zero.(no content)Complex disordered systems such as a spin glass show an even more complicated form of ergodicity breaking where the properties of the thermodynamic equilibrium state seen in practice are much more difficult to predict purely by symmetry arguments.

## Quantum Ergodicity Breaking

In quantum systems, there are two other types of quantum scarring, which further illustrate the weak-ergodicity breaking in quantum chaotic systems: perturbation-induced and many-body quantum scars.

## Applications Beyond Physics

Non-ergodicity is closely related to the problems of irreversibility and path dependence that are common themes in economics.

Links: [{"title":"Time-translation symmetry - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time-translation_symmetry"},{"title":"Time crystal - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_crystal"},{"title":"Spacetime symmetries - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spacetime_symmetries"},{"title":"Symmetry (physics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry_in_physics"},{"title":"Conservation of energy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conservation_of_energy"},{"title":"T-symmetry - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/T-symmetry"},{"title":"Translational symmetry - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Translational_symmetry"},{"title":"Time symmetry - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_symmetry"},{"title":"Symmetry - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry_transformation"},{"title":"Noether's theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noether's_theorem"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about time translation symmetry:

## Definition

Time-translation symmetry (TTS) is a mathematical transformation in physics that moves the times of events through a common interval.(no content)Time-translation symmetry is the law that the laws of physics are unchanged under such a transformation.

## How It Works

A physical system may have the same features over a certain interval of time Δt; this is expressed mathematically as invariance under the transformation t → t + a for any real parameters t and t + a in the interval.

## Connection to Conservation Laws

Time translation symmetry has a fundamental relationship with energy conservation. Temporal translation symmetry (i.e. homogeneity of time) gives rise to conservation of energy.(no content)Symmetries in nature lead directly to conservation laws, something which is precisely formulated by Noether's theorem.

## Breaking Time-Translation Symmetry

Interestingly, it's possible to break this symmetry. Time crystals, a state of matter first observed in 2017, break time-translation symmetry.

## Mathematical Structure

Time independent Hamiltonian systems form a group of time translations that is described by the non-compact, abelian, Lie group.

Based on the web search results, here's information about Coupled Map Lattice (CML):

## Overview

A coupled map lattice (CML) is a dynamical system that models the behavior of nonlinear systems (especially partial differential equations).(no content)They are predominantly used to qualitatively study the chaotic dynamics of spatially extended systems.

## How CMLs Work

The CML system evolves through discrete time by a mapping on vector sequences, with these mappings being a recursive function of two competing terms: an individual non-linear reaction, and a spatial interaction (coupling) of variable intensity.

## Classification by Coupling Strength

CMLs can be classified by the strength of their coupling parameter(s), with much of the current published work in CMLs based in weak coupled systems where diffeomorphisms of the state space close to identity are studied.(no content)Weak coupling with monotonic (bistable) dynamical regimes demonstrate spatial chaos phenomena and are popular in neural models, while weak coupling unimodal maps are characterized by their stable periodic points and are used by gene regulatory network models.(no content)Space-time chaotic phenomena can be demonstrated from chaotic mappings subject to weak coupling coefficients and are popular in phase transition phenomena models.(no content)Strong coupling interactions are most well known to model synchronization effects of dynamic spatial systems such as the Kuramoto model.

Based on the web search results, here's information about Coupled Map Lattice (CML):

## Overview

A coupled map lattice (CML) is a dynamical system that models the behavior of nonlinear systems (especially partial differential equations).(no content)They are predominantly used to qualitatively study the chaotic dynamics of spatially extended systems.

## How CMLs Work

The CML system evolves through discrete time by a mapping on vector sequences, with these mappings being a recursive function of two competing terms: an individual non-linear reaction, and a spatial interaction (coupling) of variable intensity.

## Classification by Coupling Strength

CMLs can be classified by the strength of their coupling parameter(s), with much of the current published work in CMLs based in weak coupled systems where diffeomorphisms of the state space close to identity are studied.(no content)Weak coupling with monotonic (bistable) dynamical regimes demonstrate spatial chaos phenomena and are popular in neural models, while weak coupling unimodal maps are characterized by their stable periodic points and are used by gene regulatory network models.(no content)Space-time chaotic phenomena can be demonstrated from chaotic mappings subject to weak coupling coefficients and are popular in phase transition phenomena models.(no content)Strong coupling interactions are most well known to model synchronization effects of dynamic spatial systems such as the Kuramoto model.

Wineland - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_J._Wineland"},{"title":"Penning trap - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Penning_trap"}]

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of trapped ion quantum computing:

## What is Trapped Ion Quantum Computing?

A trapped-ion quantum computer (TIQC) is one proposed approach to a large-scale quantum computer where ions, or charged atomic particles, can be confined and suspended in free space using electromagnetic fields.(no content)Qubits are stored in stable electronic states of each ion, and quantum information can be transferred through the collective quantized motion of the ions in a shared trap (interacting through the Coulomb force).

## How It Works

Lasers are applied to induce coupling between the qubit states (for single qubit operations) or coupling between the internal qubit states and the external motional states (for entanglement between qubits).

## Advantages

The fundamental operations of a quantum computer have been demonstrated experimentally with the currently highest accuracy in trapped-ion systems.(no content)This makes the trapped-ion quantum computer system one of the most promising architectures for a scalable, universal quantum computer.

## Historical Development

The first implementation scheme for a controlled-NOT quantum gate was proposed by Ignacio Cirac and Peter Zoller in 1995, specifically for the trapped-ion system, and a key step in the controlled-NOT gate was experimentally realized at NIST Ion Storage Group the same year.

## Current Progress

As of December 2023, the largest number of particles to be controllably entangled is 32 trapped ions.

Web search results for query: "Discrete time crystal"

Links: [{"title":"Time crystal - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_crystal"},{"title":"Talk:Time crystal - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Time_crystal"},{"title":"k·p perturbation theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/K.p_method"},{"title":"Crystal oscillator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crystal_oscillator"},{"title":"Crystal system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crystal_system"},{"title":"Crystal momentum - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crystal_momentum"},{"title":"Discrete time and continuous time - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discrete-time"},{"title":"Crystal oscillator frequencies - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crystal_oscillator_frequencies"},{"title":"Pierce oscillator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pierce_oscillator"},{"title":"Chronon - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chronon"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about discrete time crystals:

## What is a Discrete Time Crystal?

A discrete time crystal is a system in which discrete time-translation symmetry is broken, which may be realized in periodically driven systems.(no content)Time crystals were first proposed theoretically by Alfred Shapere and Frank Wilczek in 2012 as a time-based analogue to common crystals – whereas the atoms in crystals are arranged periodically in space, the atoms in a time crystal are arranged periodically in both space and time.

## Key Characteristics

A discrete time crystal never reaches thermal equilibrium, as it is a type (or phase) of non-equilibrium matter.(no content)Experimentally realized time crystals show discrete time-translation symmetry breaking, and they are periodically driven systems oscillating at a fraction of the frequency of the driving force.(no content)Discrete time crystals follow a strict definition: the system shows oscillations with a period longer than the driving force, the system is in crypto-equilibrium (these oscillations generate no entropy), and the system exhibits long-range order – the oscillations are in phase (synchronized) over arbitrarily long distances and time.

## Experimental Realization and Applications

Discrete time crystals have been observed in physics laboratories as early as 2016.(no content)One example of a time crystal is a constantly rotating ring of charged ions in an otherwise lowest-energy state.(no content)In terms of practical use, time crystals may one day be used as quantum computer memory.

Links: [{"title":"Quantum error correction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_error_correction"},{"title":"Threshold theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Threshold_theorem"},{"title":"Noisy intermediate-scale quantum computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noisy_intermediate-scale_quantum_era"},{"title":"Stabilizer code - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stabilizer_code"},{"title":"Quantum supremacy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_supremacy"},{"title":"Qudit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qudit"},{"title":"Nikolas Breuckmann - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nikolas_Breuckmann"},{"title":"Physical and logical qubits - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Physical_and_logical_qubits"},{"title":"Parity measurement - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parity_measurement"},{"title":"Linear optical quantum computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_optical_quantum_computing"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of error correction in quantum computing:

## What is Quantum Error Correction?

Quantum error correction (QEC) comprises a set of techniques used in quantum memory and quantum computing to protect quantum information from errors arising from decoherence and other sources of quantum noise.

## The Challenge

Compared with quantum memory, where channel-induced errors are the primary concern, the frequent application of quantum gates in quantum computation necessitates fault-tolerant design. For QECCs implemented on qubit-based platforms, fault tolerance additionally accounts for imperfect quantum gates, faulty state preparation, and measurement errors.

## Key Concepts

QEC schemes that employ codewords stabilized by a set of commuting operators are known as stabilizer codes, and the corresponding codewords are referred to as quantum error-correcting codes (QECCs).(no content)In most QECCs, the type of error is either a bit flip, or a phase flip, or both.

## The Threshold Theorem

In quantum computing, the threshold theorem states that a quantum computer with a physical error rate below a certain threshold can, through application of quantum error correction schemes, suppress the logical error rate to arbitrarily low levels.(no content)Current estimates put the threshold for the surface code on the order of 1%.

## Recent Progress

Google was the first to demonstrate that it was possible to build a logical qubit with a lower error rate than the physical qubits that constitute it. This is seen as a crucial step toward fault-tolerant quantum computers, which are necessary for practical applications.

Links: [{"title":"Quantum error correction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_error_correction"},{"title":"Threshold theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Threshold_theorem"},{"title":"Noisy intermediate-scale quantum computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noisy_intermediate-scale_quantum_era"},{"title":"Stabilizer code - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stabilizer_code"},{"title":"Quantum supremacy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_supremacy"},{"title":"Qudit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qudit"},{"title":"Nikolas Breuckmann - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nikolas_Breuckmann"},{"title":"Physical and logical qubits - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Physical_and_logical_qubits"},{"title":"Parity measurement - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parity_measurement"},{"title":"Linear optical quantum computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_optical_quantum_computing"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of error correction in quantum computing:

## What is Quantum Error Correction?

Quantum error correction (QEC) comprises a set of techniques used in quantum memory and quantum computing to protect quantum information from errors arising from decoherence and other sources of quantum noise.

## The Challenge

Compared with quantum memory, where channel-induced errors are the primary concern, the frequent application of quantum gates in quantum computation necessitates fault-tolerant design. For QECCs implemented on qubit-based platforms, fault tolerance additionally accounts for imperfect quantum gates, faulty state preparation, and measurement errors.

## Key Concepts

QEC schemes that employ codewords stabilized by a set of commuting operators are known as stabilizer codes, and the corresponding codewords are referred to as quantum error-correcting codes (QECCs).(no content)In most QECCs, the type of error is either a bit flip, or a phase flip, or both.

## The Threshold Theorem

In quantum computing, the threshold theorem states that a quantum computer with a physical error rate below a certain threshold can, through application of quantum error correction schemes, suppress the logical error rate to arbitrarily low levels.(no content)Current estimates put the threshold for the surface code on the order of 1%.

## Recent Progress

Google was the first to demonstrate that it was possible to build a logical qubit with a lower error rate than the physical qubits that constitute it. This is seen as a crucial step toward fault-tolerant quantum computers, which are necessary for practical applications.

Links: [{"title":"Faraday wave - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Faraday_wave"},{"title":"Maxwell's equations - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maxwell's_equations"},{"title":"Faraday effect - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Faraday_effect"},{"title":"History of electromagnetic theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_electromagnetic_theory"},{"title":"Standing wave - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Standing_wave"},{"title":"James Clerk Maxwell - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Clerk_Maxwell"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Reference desk/Archives/Science/2007 November 23 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Reference_desk/Archives/Science/2007_November_23"},{"title":"Faraday cage - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Faraday_cage"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about Faraday waves:

## Overview

Faraday waves, also known as Faraday ripples and named after Michael Faraday (1791–1867), are nonlinear standing waves that appear on liquids enclosed by a vibrating receptacle.(no content)When the vibration frequency exceeds a critical value, the flat hydrostatic surface becomes unstable.

## Scientific Significance

The Faraday wave and its wavelength is analogous to the de Broglie wave with the de Broglie wavelength in de Broglie–Bohm theory in the field of quantum mechanics.

## Applications

Faraday waves are used as a liquid-based template for directed assembly of microscale materials including soft matter, rigid bodies, and biological entities. Unlike solid-based templates, this liquid-based template can be dynamically changed by tuning vibrational frequency and acceleration and generate diverse sets of symmetrical and periodic patterns.(no content)This effect can also be used for mixing two liquids acoustically, as Faraday waves form on the interface between the two liquids, which increases the surface area between them, rapidly and thoroughly mixing the liquids.

## Natural Occurrence

Interestingly, this phenomenon is also used by alligators to call mates—they vibrate their lungs at low frequencies slightly below the surface, causing their spikes to move and induce surface waves that are basically Faraday waves.

Web search results for query: "Localization quantum mechanics"

Links: [{"title":"Many-body localization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Many-body_localization"},{"title":"Anderson localization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anderson_localization"},{"title":"Principle of locality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Principle_of_locality"},{"title":"Wave packet - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wave_packet"},{"title":"Newton–Wigner localization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newton–Wigner_localization"},{"title":"Localization-protected quantum order - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Localization-protected_quantum_order"},{"title":"Localized molecular orbitals - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Localized_molecular_orbitals"},{"title":"Weak localization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weak_localization"},{"title":"Objective-collapse theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Objective-collapse_theory"},{"title":"Ghirardi–Rimini–Weber theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ghirardi%E2%80%93Rimini%E2%80%93Weber_theory"}]

Here are the search results for "Localization quantum mechanics":

## Overview

The search results reveal several important concepts related to localization in quantum mechanics:

### Anderson Localization

Anderson localization (also known as strong localization) is the absence of diffusion of waves in a disordered medium, named after physicist P. W. Anderson, who suggested that electron localization is possible in a lattice potential if the disorder is sufficiently large. Anderson localization is a general wave phenomenon that applies to the transport of electromagnetic waves, acoustic waves, quantum waves, spin waves, etc.

### Many-Body Localization (MBL)

Many-body localization is a dynamical phenomenon occurring in isolated many-body quantum systems, characterized by the system failing to reach thermal equilibrium and retaining a memory of its initial condition in local observables for infinite times. MBL was first proposed by P.W. Anderson in 1958 as a possibility that could arise in strongly disordered quantum systems.

### Weak Localization

Weak localization is a physical effect which occurs in disordered electronic systems at very low temperatures, manifesting itself as a positive correction to the resistivity of a metal or semiconductor, and is a precursor of Anderson localization which occurs at strong disorder.

### Localization-Protected Quantum Order

The suppression of thermal fluctuations in localized systems can allow for new kinds of order that are forbidden in equilibrium—which is the essence of localization-protected quantum order.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Solid-state spin systems"

Links: [{"title":"Spintronics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spintronics"},{"title":"Spin (physics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spin_(physics)"},{"title":"Quantum spin liquid - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_spin_liquid"},{"title":"Solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solid-state_nuclear_magnetic_resonance"},{"title":"Spin states (d electrons) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spin_states_(d_electrons)"},{"title":"Spin–orbit interaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spin–orbit_interaction"},{"title":"Solid-state physics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solid_state_physics"},{"title":"Spin model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spin_model"},{"title":"Spin glass - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spin_glass"},{"title":"Spin density wave - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spin_density_wave"}]

Here's what I found about solid-state spin systems:

## Overview

In a solid, the spins of many electrons can act together to affect the magnetic and electronic properties of a material, for example endowing it with a permanent magnetic moment as in a ferromagnet. This is a fundamental aspect of solid-state physics and condensed matter research.

## Key Research Areas

Several important types of solid-state spin systems are being studied:

**Spintronics**: Spintronics (a portmanteau of spin transport electronics), also known as spin electronics, is the study of the intrinsic spin of the electron and its associated magnetic moment, in addition to its fundamental electronic charge, in solid-state devices.

**Spin Models**: The study of the behavior of spin models is a thriving area of research in condensed matter physics. For instance, the Ising model describes spins (dipoles) that have only two possible states, up and down, whereas in the Heisenberg model the spin vector is allowed to point in any direction. In certain magnets, the magnetic dipoles are only free to rotate in a 2D plane, a system which can be adequately described by the so-called xy-model.

**Quantum Spin Liquids**: One intuitive description of this state is as a "liquid" of disordered spins, in comparison to a ferromagnetic spin state, much in the way liquid water is in a disordered state compared to crystalline ice. However, unlike other disordered states, a quantum spin liquid state preserves its disorder to very low temperatures.

**Spin Glass**: In condensed matter physics, a spin glass is a magnetic state characterized by randomness, besides cooperative behavior in freezing of spins at a temperature called the "freezing temperature," Tf.

These systems have important applications in quantum computing, materials science, and information technology.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "Superconducting qubit"

Links: [{"title":"Superconducting quantum computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superconducting_quantum_computing"},{"title":"Transmon - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transmon"},{"title":"Phase qubit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phase_qubit"},{"title":"Charge qubit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charge_qubit"},{"title":"Flux qubit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flux_qubit"},{"title":"Yasunobu Nakamura - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yasunobu_Nakamura"},{"title":"File:Superconducting qubits electrical diagrams.pdf - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Superconducting_qubits_electrical_diagrams.pdf"},{"title":"Circuit quantum electrodynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Circuit_quantum_electrodynamics"},{"title":"Qubit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qubit"},{"title":"Cat qubit quantum computer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cat_qubit_quantum_computer"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about superconducting qubits:

## Overview

A qubit is a generalization of a bit capable of occupying a quantum superposition of both states. Superconducting qubits represent one of the most promising approaches to building quantum computers.

## Basic Principles

Superconductors are implemented at low temperatures where they have infinite conductivity and zero resistance. Each qubit is built using semiconductor circuits with an LC circuit: a capacitor and an inductor. Superconducting capacitors and inductors are used to produce a resonant circuit that dissipates almost no energy, as heat can disrupt quantum information.(no content)In superconductors, the basic charge carriers are pairs of electrons (known as Cooper pairs), rather than single fermions as found in typical conductors. Electrons forming Cooper pairs possess equal and opposite momentum and spin so that the total spin of the Cooper pair is an integer spin. Hence, Cooper pairs are bosons.

## Key Components

One distinguishable attribute of superconducting quantum circuits is the use of Josephson junctions. Josephson junctions are superconducting elements with a nonlinear inductance, which is important for qubit implementation. The use of this nonlinear element in the resonant superconducting circuit produces uneven spacing between the energy levels.

## Operation

Superconducting quantum computing devices are typically designed in the radio-frequency spectrum, cooled in dilution refrigerators below 15 mK and addressed with conventional electronic instruments, e.g. frequency synthesizers and spectrum analyzers.

## Types of Superconducting Qubits

Several varieties exist, including:
- **Transmon qubits**: The transmon has become the workhorse of many leading quantum computing platforms due to its exceptional coherence properties, with recent demonstrations achieving coherence times exceeding 100 μs.
- **Flux qubits**: Flux qubits are micrometer sized loops of superconducting metal that is interrupted by a number of Josephson junctions.
- **Charge qubits**: A charge qubit is formed by a tiny superconducting island coupled by a Josephson junction to a superconducting reservoir.

## Manufacturing

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about superconducting qubits:

## Overview

A qubit is a generalization of a bit capable of occupying a quantum superposition of both states. Superconducting qubits represent one of the most promising approaches to building quantum computers.

## Basic Principles

Superconductors are implemented at low temperatures where they have infinite conductivity and zero resistance. Each qubit is built using semiconductor circuits with an LC circuit: a capacitor and an inductor. Superconducting capacitors and inductors are used to produce a resonant circuit that dissipates almost no energy, as heat can disrupt quantum information.(no content)In superconductors, the basic charge carriers are pairs of electrons (known as Cooper pairs), rather than single fermions as found in typical conductors. Electrons forming Cooper pairs possess equal and opposite momentum and spin so that the total spin of the Cooper pair is an integer spin. Hence, Cooper pairs are bosons.

## Key Components

One distinguishable attribute of superconducting quantum circuits is the use of Josephson junctions. Josephson junctions are superconducting elements with a nonlinear inductance, which is important for qubit implementation. The use of this nonlinear element in the resonant superconducting circuit produces uneven spacing between the energy levels.

## Operation

Superconducting quantum computing devices are typically designed in the radio-frequency spectrum, cooled in dilution refrigerators below 15 mK and addressed with conventional electronic instruments, e.g. frequency synthesizers and spectrum analyzers.

## Types of Superconducting Qubits

Several varieties exist, including:
- **Transmon qubits**: The transmon has become the workhorse of many leading quantum computing platforms due to its exceptional coherence properties, with recent demonstrations achieving coherence times exceeding 100 μs.
- **Flux qubits**: Flux qubits are micrometer sized loops of superconducting metal that is interrupted by a number of Josephson junctions.
- **Charge qubits**: A charge qubit is formed by a tiny superconducting island coupled by a Josephson junction to a superconducting reservoir.

## Manufacturing

Manufacturing superconducting qubits follows a process involving lithography, depositing of metal, etching, and controlled oxidation.

Based on the search results, here's information about many-body localization in quantum systems:

## Definition and Basic Concept

Many-body localization (MBL) is a dynamical phenomenon occurring in isolated many-body quantum systems, characterized by the system failing to reach thermal equilibrium and retaining a memory of its initial condition in local observables for infinite times.

## Historical Development

MBL was first proposed by P.W. Anderson in 1958 as a possibility that could arise in strongly disordered quantum systems.(no content)In 1980 Fleishman and Anderson demonstrated the phenomenon survived the addition of interactions to lowest order in perturbation theory.(no content)In 2014 Imbrie presented a proof of MBL for certain one dimensional spin chains with strong disorder, with the localization being stable to arbitrary local perturbations.

## Key Properties

In MBL systems, memory of initial conditions remains accessible in local observables at long times.(no content)In MBL systems, energy eigenstates do not obey the eigenstate thermalization hypothesis (ETH) and have area law entanglement entropy.(no content)MBL enables the formation of exotic forms of quantum order that could not arise in thermal equilibrium, through the phenomenon of localization-protected quantum order.

## Experimental Observations

A number of experiments have been reported observing the MBL phenomenon, with most of these experiments involving synthetic quantum systems, such as assemblies of ultracold atoms or trapped ions.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about many-body quantum simulators:

## Overview

Many important problems in physics, especially low-temperature physics and many-body physics, remain poorly understood because the underlying quantum mechanics is vastly complex, and conventional computers are inadequate for simulating quantum systems with as few as 30 particles because the dimension of the Hilbert space grows exponentially with particle number.

## What are Quantum Simulators?

Quantum simulators provide an alternative route to understanding the properties of many-body systems.(no content)Quantum simulators permit the study of a quantum system in a programmable fashion, and in this instance, simulators are special purpose devices designed to provide insight about specific physics problems.

## Implementation Platforms

Quantum simulators have been realized on a number of experimental platforms, including systems of ultracold quantum gases, polar molecules, trapped ions, photonic systems, quantum dots, and superconducting circuits.

## Trapped Ion Simulators Example

The trapped-ion simulator consists of a tiny, single-plane crystal of hundreds of beryllium ions, less than 1 millimeter in diameter, hovering inside a device called a Penning trap, where the outermost electron of each ion acts as a tiny quantum magnet and is used as a qubit.

## Advantages Over Classical Simulation

Classical computers seem to require exponential time to simulate many-particle quantum systems, yet quantum many-body systems are able to "solve themselves."

Links: [{"title":"Quantum dissipation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_dissipation"},{"title":"Open quantum system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_quantum_system"},{"title":"Fluctuation-dissipation theorem","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fluctuation-dissipation_theorem"},{"title":"Dissipative system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dissipative_system"},{"title":"Quantum dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_dynamics"},{"title":"Quantum decoherence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_decoherence"},{"title":"Zero-point energy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zero-point_energy"},{"title":"Fluctuation theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fluctuation_theorem"},{"title":"Dephasing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dephasing"},{"title":"Quantum turbulence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_turbulence"}]

I've found comprehensive information about dissipation in quantum systems. Here's an overview of the key findings:

## What is Quantum Dissipation?

Quantum dissipation is the branch of physics that studies the quantum analogues of the process of irreversible loss of energy observed at the classical level, with its main purpose being to derive the laws of classical dissipation from the framework of quantum mechanics.

## Key Concepts and Applications

In the context of quantum computation, dissipation represents a qubit coupled to an environment, which can produce decoherence.(no content)In the study of amorphous solids, it provides the basis of the standard theory to describe their thermodynamic properties, and the dissipative two-level system represents a paradigm in the study of quantum phase transitions.

## The Caldeira-Leggett Model

In 1981, Amir Caldeira and Anthony J. Leggett proposed a simple model to study in detail the way dissipation arises from a quantum point of view, which describes a quantum particle in one dimension coupled to a bath.

## Open Quantum Systems

No quantum system is perfectly isolated from its environment, and a system that interacts with its surroundings is known as an open quantum system, with this interaction leading to a non-unitary evolution, where information and energy can be exchanged with the environment.(no content)The dissipator or Lindbladian describes the irreversible, non-unitary dynamics due to the environment, with Lindblad operators (quantum jump operators) modeling the specific ways the system is coupled to the bath.

## Fluctuation-Dissipation Theorem

The fluctuation–dissipation theorem is a powerful tool in statistical physics for predicting the behavior of systems that obey detailed balance.(no content)The fluctuation–dissipation theorem applies both to classical and quantum mechanical systems and was proven by Herbert Callen and Theodore Welton in 1951.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
Perfect! I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper on discrete time crystals. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** Survey
- This is a Colloquium paper that reviews recent theoretical and experimental advances in quantum and classical discrete time crystals

**Triples Extracted:** 14 entities identified

The analysis identified and validated 14 key concepts, methods, and tools mentioned in the paper:

1. **Time crystal** - The primary subject matter
2. **Time-translation symmetry** - The fundamental symmetry being broken
3. **Ergodicity** - Key mechanism for discrete time crystal behavior
4. **Josephson effect** - Related quantum phenomenon
5. **Coupled map lattice** - Classical system showing similar phenomena
6. **Faraday wave** - Classical analog of discrete time crystal behavior
7. **Many-body localization** - Strategy for stabilizing time crystalline order
8. **Thermalisation** - Related to prethermalization mechanism
9. **Quantum dissipation** - Strategy for stabilizing in open systems
10. **Quantum error correction** - Stability approach for quantum systems
11. **Quantum simulator** - Main experimental platform
12. **Trapped-ion quantum computer** - Experimental implementation platform
13. **Spintronics** - Represents solid-state spin systems platform
14. **Superconducting quantum computing** - Experimental platform using superconducting qubits

All Wikipedia URLs have been verified and the validation script confirms the JSON structure is correct with all required fields populated.

Sources:
- [Time crystal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_crystal)
- [Time-translation symmetry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time-translation_symmetry)
- [Ergodicity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ergodicity)
- [Josephson effect](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Josephson_effect)
- [Coupled map lattice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coupled_map_lattice)
- [Faraday wave](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Faraday_wave)
- [Many-body localization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Many-body_localization)
- [Thermalisation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thermalisation)
- [Quantum dissipation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_dissipation)
- [Quantum error correction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_error_correction)
- [Quantum simulator](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_simulator)
- [Trapped-ion quantum computer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trapped-ion_quantum_computer)
- [Spintronics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spintronics)
- [Superconducting quantum computing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superconducting_quantum_computing)
